image.altText: Lilie James, who was killed at St Andrew's Cathedral School in Sydney's CBD on October 25, 2023, smiling in an undated selfie

items.synopsis: The grandmother of 21-year-old Lilie James says she was a "beautiful young woman" as she recalled memories of Lilie as a child. Today, staff and students return for a memorial service to the school where she was killed.

title.children: Lilie James's family 'cannot understand' why she was killed at Sydney school

image.altText: Three stills from mobile phone footage of an elderly woman being dragged across the ground by a security guard.

items.synopsis: The public is paying for private security guards to patrol city streets, but they are in the dark about just what powers these guards have been given.

title.children: Elderly Aboriginal woman repeatedly dragged across the ground by government-funded security guards

image.altText: A young boy with tears on his cheeks is carried by a man out of a van

items.synopsis: In this war between Israel and Hamas, we are in unprecedented territory. The civilian death toll has become so heavy so quickly, and yet Western leaders aren't expressly calling for a ceasefire, writes John Lyons.

title.children: A confronting question that needs an answer: Is the killing of almost 1,000 children a week self-defence?

image.altText: A photo shot from the perspective of an armoured vehicle showing tanks on a beach.

items.synopsis: As Israel releases pictures appearing to show an intent to encircle Gaza's main city, the military says calls for Palestinians to evacuate southward are now "urgent".

title.children: Latest updates: Gaza evacuation call now 'urgent' as rioters storm Russian airport to protest plane from Israel

image.altText: A red R-F-S fire truck in front of burning trees.

items.synopsis: A small increase of just 10 to 20 degrees Celsius in the air temperature from one day to the next can play a critical role in determining a fire threat.

title.children: The real reason hot weather leads to bushfires

image.altText: A bottle of sparkling wine is about to be poured

items.synopsis: A massive trade deal with the European Union appears all but doomed after "endgame" negotiations between the two sides collapsed before they even began.

title.children: Australian producers to keep prosecco, feta and parmesan as EU trade deal doomed

image.altText: Eddie Jones looks pensive after the Wallabies lost to Fiji at the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

items.synopsis: Eddie Jones has walked away from Australian rugby after handing in his resignation as Wallabies coach.

title.children: Eddie Jones ends disastrous Australian return and resigns as Wallabies coach

image.altText: Cast of Friends walk together.

items.synopsis: College roommate, secret lover, best friend, proud duck owner — Chandler Bing was a well-loved Friend, and one that gave us many laughs over the course of 10 seasons of the hit sitcom.

title.children: He wasn't the smartest, most successful or strongest, but Chandler Bing was an underdog we loved

image.altText: A file phot of the cast of the hit television series Friends sitting on a red couch.

items.synopsis: Family, fellow actors and Friends creators have spoken publicly of their heartbreak over the 54-year-old's passing.

title.children: Friends, family and co-stars pay tribute to Matthew Perry

items.synopsis: Gregory Smith has gone from a homeless forest dweller and a broken man to a PhD graduate, OAM recipient, board member, writer, doting dad and partner. His redemption story is remarkable.

title.children: Gregory Smith became a dad again in his mid-60s. It's the best thing that's happened to him

image.altText: Palestinians carry a child casualty at the site of an Israeli strike on a house, in Khan Younis

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has criticised the government for abstaining from voting a United Nations motion for a truce between Israel and Hamas, labelling the prime minister "weak".

title.children: 'Seeking political advantage out of this terrible conflict': Australian government hits back at UN vote criticism

image.altText: Surf Life savers carry and inflatable boat in the beach

items.synopsis: Search crews say a man was last seen by friends caught in a rip after entering the water at a Wollongong beach.

title.children: Lifesavers help search for swimmer last seen with 'hand in the air' at unpatrolled beach

image.altText: ABC reporter Keely Johnson stands with her arms crossed in front of cars in a carpark.

items.synopsis: When I needed a new starter motor for my car, my dad thought the mechanic's price was a bit steep. So, he called himself — and was quoted $200 less than I was.

title.children: I had a bad experience at the mechanic. After talking to other women, it seems I'm not alone

image.altText: Olympique Lyonnais coach Fabio Grosso is led down a hallway, holding his face in his hands.

items.synopsis: Italian soccer World Cup winner Fabio Grosso is left bloodied and dazed as fans attack a bus carrying his Lyon team to a match in Marseille.

title.children: French football game called off after fans smash windows on visiting team's bus, leaving coach bloodied

image.altText: A ice hockey player mid game

items.synopsis: Adam Johnson, 29, is being remembered as an outstanding player and incredible person after receiving the fatal injury in a game for the Nottingham Panthers.

title.children: Ice hockey player dead after neck slashed by skate during game in England

image.altText: Two women dressed in white jackets, hair nets and protective ear muffs stand near a conveyer belt packing meat.

items.synopsis: While beef producers with Australia's largest meat cooperative, the Casino Food Co-op, enjoyed record prices last year, it resulted in a massive hit to its processing business.

title.children: Record beef prices spur $11 million loss for Australia's largest meat processor

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: The ASX is trading lower, with gold miners the only group to gain as the precious metal passes $US2,000 an ounce, while Qantas has filed its defence against the ACCC's ghost flight claims. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas files defence against ACCC's claims it sold tickets for cancelled flights, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Retail spending data for September has come in much stronger than expected, rising by 0.9% during the month — the largest rise since January. It follows an increase of 0.3% in August, and a 0.6% rise in July, according to the ABS. "The strong rise in September came from a diverse range of factors across the Retail industry," said Ben Dorber, head of retail statistics at the ABS. “The warmer-than-usual start to spring lifted turnover at departments stores, household goods and clothing retailers, with more spending on hardware, gardening, and clothing items. "While the rise in September was the largest since January, subdued spending for most of 2023 means that underlying growth in retail turnover remains historically low ." So what does this mean for interest rates? According to the Commonwealth Bank, it's weighing favourably in the "rate hike" camp for the RBA. "Aussie retail sales rose at a solid pace in September, beating market estimates, suggesting that an interest rate hike could come as soon as next week, " CBA economist Craig James said. "The 0.9% lift in consumer spending last month was the biggest since January, suggesting that p essimistic Aussie households are continuing to spend, withstanding higher borrowing costs and persistent price pressures. "The bottom line is that high deposit rates and the strong Aussie job market are still supporting consumption. "While slowing consumption and the lagged effect of previous rate hikes have been key factors in the Reserve Bank's five rate pauses this year, the unexpected strengthening in spending adds to the case for a potential resumption of the rate hiking cycle on November 7. " But it's not all bad news, according to Tom Kennedy from JP Morgan. "We expect these factors will deliver a temporary/one-off boost with the pace of sales growth to slow in coming months ," he said. "The retail survey is skewed toward goods spending and overlooks much of the services sector (save for restaurant/cafes) where consumption has proven more resilient." "As such we expect broader measures of household consumption to outpace the retail data, albeit still show signs of moderation as higher borrowing costs and diminished savings buffers weigh on discretionary spending."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Stronger than forecast retail spending data in September adds to rate hike risk

children.content: Retail spending data for September has come in much stronger than expected,
rising by 0.9% during the month
— the largest rise since January.
It follows an increase of 0.3% in August, and a 0.6% rise in July, according to the ABS.
"The strong rise in September came from a diverse range of factors across the Retail industry," said Ben Dorber, head of retail statistics at the ABS.
“The warmer-than-usual start to spring
lifted turnover at departments stores, household goods and clothing retailers
, with more spending on hardware, gardening, and clothing items.
"While
the rise in September was the largest since January
, subdued spending for most of 2023 means that
underlying growth in retail turnover remains historically low
So what does this mean for interest rates? According to the Commonwealth Bank, it's weighing favourably in the "rate hike" camp for the RBA.
"Aussie retail sales rose at a solid pace in September, beating market estimates,
suggesting that an interest rate hike could come as soon as next week,
" CBA economist Craig James said.
"The 0.9% lift in consumer spending last month was the biggest since January, suggesting that p
essimistic Aussie households are continuing to spend, withstanding higher borrowing costs and persistent price pressures
"The bottom line is that
high deposit rates and the strong Aussie job market are still supporting consumption
"While slowing consumption and the lagged effect of previous rate hikes have been key factors in the Reserve Bank's five rate pauses this year
, the unexpected strengthening in spending adds to the case for a potential resumption of the rate hiking cycle on November 7.
But it's not all bad news, according to
Tom Kennedy
from
JP Morgan
"We expect these factors will
deliver a temporary/one-off boost with the pace of sales growth to slow in coming months
," he said.
"The retail survey is
skewed toward goods spending and overlooks much of the services sector
(save for restaurant/cafes) where consumption has proven more resilient."

"As such we expect broader measures of household consumption to outpace the retail data, albeit still show signs of moderation as higher borrowing costs and diminished savings buffers weigh on discretionary spending."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Viva Energy could be one of the 'bloke-iest' companies in Australia; it has a branded motor racing team and sells industrial lubricants and grease. It's an unlikely suspect to be bridging the gender pay gap — but that's exactly what's happening after the company made deliberate changes to get more women into roles traditionally dominated by men. The company has since narrowed its gender pay gap to just 9.9% — less than half of what it is at most businesses in Australia. So how have they done it, and are other companies going to follow suit before mandatory reporting comes into effect next year? My colleague, business reporter Daniel Ziffer took a closer look at how the gender pay gap can be fixed, and you can read his story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How one of Australia's 'bloke-iest' companies is taking on the gender pay gap — and winning

featuredLink.title: How to fix the gender pay gap, according to one of the 'bloke-iest' companies in Australia

The company has since

— less than half of what it is at most businesses in Australia.
So how have they done it, and are other companies going to follow suit before mandatory reporting comes into effect next year?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas is denying allegations that it sold tickets for flights that had already been cancelled but has conceded it let customers down and mistakes were made. The airline has denied profiting from delayed or cancelled flights and says the ACCC's case ignores the reality of the aviation industry that "airlines can't guarantee specific flights". You can hear the full rundown from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 🎧 Qantas rejects ACCC's 'ghost flight' allegations but admits customer failings

children.content: Qantas is denying allegations that it sold tickets for flights that had already been cancelled but has conceded it let customers down and mistakes were made.
The airline has denied profiting from delayed or cancelled flights and says the ACCC's case ignores the reality of the aviation industry that "airlines can't guarantee specific flights".
You can hear the full rundown from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan below:

image.altText: Nathan and Sophie Streeter wear Christmassy clothes in a hospital with Charlie laying on Nathan's chest.

items.synopsis: After the Streeters lost their newborn son to necrotising enterocolitis (NEC), they began a journey to build awareness and support for research into the devastating condition.

title.children: Born premature, Charlie had just begun to see 'light at the end of the tunnel'. Then he was hit by a killer disease

image.altText: A woman wears a blue skull mask with glamorous hair amid a collage of other spooky faces on a neon background.

items.synopsis: From the shiniest new horrors to overlooked gems and oddball reboots, here's our pick of shows to watch this Halloween that are equal parts trick and treat.

title.children: Goosebumps is back. Plus six more shows to (trick or) treat yourself to this spooky season

image.altText: Bruce Fairfax, photographed with his dog.

items.synopsis: The Tasmanian man was reported missing on a bushwalk with his wife and their dog six years ago but now police say they're reinterviewing old witnesses.

title.children: Bruce Fairfax and his wife went for a bushwalk six years ago. What happened is now part of a criminal probe

image.altText: A close up of long, green grass.

items.synopsis: A council in the state's south-east has proposed a local law restricting grass growth to 30 centimetres, but farmers say it's "just not feasible".

title.children: Council's plan to impose grass height limit angers locals in regional Victoria

image.altText: Matildas coach Tony Gustavsson looks towards the stands and applauds as he reacts to a win.

items.synopsis: The Matildas are already through to the next round of Olympic qualifying, but coach Tony Gustavsson says his team is not backing off and they still want to go all-out against Chinese Taipei in Perth.

title.children: Matildas coach Tony Gustavsson's new problem — he has more form players than spots in the side

image.altText: Associate Professor Astghik Mavisakalyan

items.synopsis: In early 2024, more than 4.6 million workers are about to find out how much less the company they work for pays female staff. Many companies are working now to fix the problem.

title.children: How to fix the gender pay gap, according to one of the 'bloke-iest' companies in Australia

image.altText: A man in a hospital bed, with a canula in his hand, does a hang loose symbol.

items.synopsis: The resounding message of the Safe Work Australia report into silicosis is simple: Ban engineered stone benchtops and save worker lives. So what will make governments act, asks Adele Ferguson.

title.children: 'The only way to stop it is to ban it': The battle to stop engineered stone killing workers

image.altText: A wooden, historic timber woolshed with gate and wooden fence

items.synopsis: A restoration project for the National Trust-listed Warrock Homestead, western Victoria's oldest pastoral station, is uncovering nearly two centuries of treasures at the site known for being the birthplace of Australia's working dog.

title.children: 36 buildings, an affair, and the birthplace of kelpies all front of mind during 180-year-old homestead's restoration

image.altText: The outline of four women, kept anonymous, superimposed over shattered glass

items.synopsis: Elisabeth Armitage will spend the two next weeks hearing from experts and institutions about where the NT domestic violence system has failed, and how it can improve.

title.children: NT coroner to resume domestic violence inquiry examining killings of four Aboriginal women

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: The number of available properties listed to rent fell to a record low in September, with worsening vacancy rates and a rising population increasing competition among renters that's resulting in higher prices.

title.children: The reversal of a pandemic trend has rents soaring again. Is it the new normal or is the end in sight?

image.altText: A man wearing a blue and white button up shirt leans his elbow on a fence and looks out over the beach

items.synopsis: Seok Hee Lee grew up in Australia after immigrating from South Korea nearly two decades ago. When his mum applied for a visa, he was considered a dependent child. But after years of waiting for the application to be processed, Mr Lee's application was denied — because he is now an adult.

title.children: Lengthy parent visa processing times pose challenges for children

image.altText: A woman in yellow jumper holding shopping bag faces a supermarket shelf full of colourful wrapped foods.

items.synopsis: An RBA rates rise announcement could bring more bad news for people struggling in the cost-of-living crisis. How did we get here and where can you turn for help if you need it?

title.children: With rates tipped to rise yet again, why is it so hard to bring inflation down?

image.altText: Kevin Magnussen crashes out of the 2023 Mexico City Grand Prix

items.synopsis: Max Verstappen's domination of Formula 1 continues with his 16th grand prix win of the season.

title.children: F1 record broken, Aussies score points, massive crash stops race in Mexico

image.altText: a woman lifting weights while squatting with a serious expression on her face.

items.synopsis: Heather Ostler's training gym is five-hour journey from her home in regional New South Wales. But that hasn't stopped the mother of four from claiming three gold medals in the sport she loves.

title.children: After catching the 'powerlifting bug', Heather is now a three time world champion and record holder
